[Academic Warning and Suspension](https://aappm.psu.edu/policy/i-1-academic-difficulty-and-recovery) are intended to guide students in identifying and addressing the factor(s) that led to their academic difficulty. They are meant to help get you back on track and prevent further academic or financial consequences.
Students whose cumulative grade point average (GPA) falls below 2.

00 are in [Academic Warning](https://www.registrar.psu.edu/academic-progress/). A registration hold is in place until a student works with an [academic adviser](https://psu.starfishsolutions.com/starfish-ops/instructor/serviceCatalog.html#/) on an academic recovery plan.
Students who actively engage with goal-

setting and talking with an academic adviser are often successful in regaining good [academic standing](https://senate.psu.edu/students/policies-and-rules-for-undergraduate-students/54-00-academic-progress/).

concat.scalar: There are [resources on campus](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/caps-campuses) to help you with your eating disorder. Penn State offers the [Healthy Eating and Living Support (HEALS)](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/health-promotion/healthy-eating-and-nutrition/heals) program, which is a multidisciplinary program that supports healthy eating and decision-

making among students with mild to moderate eating and body image concerns. The HEALS team consists of medical providers, dietitians, and mental health professionals who provide education, resources, and support to students affected by mild to moderate concerns with eating and body image.
You can also reach out to the [National Eating Disorders Association (NEDA)](https://www.

allianceforeatingdisorders.com/), the largest nonprofit organization dedicated to supporting individuals and families affected by eating disorders, which serves as a catalyst for prevention, cures, and access to quality care.
Additionally,

Penn State's Nutrition Clinic at University Park offers registered dietitians who can help you identify dangerous dietary behaviors that may contribute to the development of an eating disorder, make appropriate referrals, and design a nutritious meal plan within limited financial resources. You can schedule an appointment with the Nutrition Clinic by calling <a href="tel:18148630461">1-814-863-
0461 or through myUHS.

Each [Penn State campus](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/caps-campuses) has a unique set of mental health resources including wellness and prevention, [counseling service](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling), and urgent/emergency services, such as the 24/7 [Penn State Crisis Line](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/crisis-intervention) <a href="tel:18772296400">1-877-229-

6400 or crisis textline (text LIONS to 741741).
Penn Stateâ€™s Counseling and Psychological Services (CAPS) offers [individual counseling](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/getting-started/individual-counseling) where you can talk to someone about a traumatic experience that you had, among other things. These services are short-term,
although a referral to a [community provider](https://psu-university-park.thrivingcampus.com/) for longer-term services may be recommended.

There are lots of ways to study abroad at Penn State. [Learn more about](https://global.psu.edu/category/students) the ways to study abroad, the [programs available](https://ea.psu.edu/index.cfm?FuseAction=Programs.SimpleSearch), and how to apply.
You should be talking with your [academic adviser](https://psu.starfishsolutions.com/starfish-ops/instructor/serviceCatalog.

html#/) about what degree requirements can be met while abroad and how that will affect your graduation timeline. You can also talk to an Education Abroad peer or staff adviser about [opportunities](https://global.psu.edu/category/steps-study-abroad).
The Education Abroad office administers a variety of program types in order to meet the needs of all Penn State students.
You do not need to participate in a student abroad program associated with your college.
You can learn more about study abroad [costs and financial aid](https://global.psu.edu/category/costs-and-funding).

concat.scalar: A [Faculty Senate petition](https://senate.psu.edu/students/student-petitions/) is a request to the Senate Committee on Education's Subcommittee on Undergraduate Petition Review for an exception to a policy listed in the Policies and Rules for Undergraduate Students. You may need a Faculty Senate petition if you have not followed a policy and believe an exception to the policy may be warranted.

Common petition types include retroactive withdrawals, late course drops, late course adds, and retroactive administrative cancellation of a course.
To submit a petition, you should first discuss your intent with your [academic adviser](https://psu.starfishsolutions.com/starfish-ops/instructor/serviceCatalog.html#/) and then work with your adviser to put together a complete packet.

concat.scalar: [CAPS Chat](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/wellness-services/caps-chat) at Penn State University Park provides informal, drop-in consultation for students with counselors from Penn State Counseling & Psychological Services (CAPS). Meetings are free and no call to CAPS is necessary: same day scheduling is available online from 8:00 AM to 4:00 PM for both virtual and in-person meetings!

Timeslots are available on a first-come, first-served basis. Meetings are no longer than 30 minutes. CAPS Chat is NOT for formal treatment, emergency and crisis services, or severe and longstanding concerns. CAPS Chat is for Discussing specific concerns in a one-on-one environment, learning more about what counseling might be like, understanding how to help a friend,
and getting mental health questions answered.

concat.scalar:
Students often combine interests through majors and minors. A double major at Penn State is called a Concurrent Major. Specific information regarding concurrent majors can be found in [policy M-3: Concurrent and Sequential Majors Programs](https://aappm.psu.edu/policy/m-3-concurrent-and-sequential-majors-programs).
[To declare a minor](https://aappm.psu.edu/policy/l-6-minors-entrance-

and-certification), students must use LionPATH unless the minor has a Faculty Senate-approved entrance requirement, such as an audition or portfolio review, or carries restrictions necessitated by explicit articulation or licensing requirements. Under these circumstances, LionPATH will generate an automatic message referring the student to the unit with administrative oversight.

You should talk with an academic adviser about your interests, especially for help in thinking about how to best combine degree requirements efficiently.
If you are considering adding or dropping a concurrent major or minor, please [meet with an academic adviser](https://psu.mediaspace.kaltura.

com/media/Make+an+Appointment+in+Starfish/1_xars485x) to talk about how this could affects your degree progress. a-bias-report).

An undergraduate degree candidate's semester classification is based on the number of total credits earned. The [University Registrar website](https://www.registrar.psu.edu/enrollment/semester-classification.cfm) provides a semester classification chart for you to determine your semester standing.
Semester classification plays an important role in a variety of university processes,

such as class scheduling, tuition calculation, and eligibility for certain campus services (parking, change of campus assignment).
If you have specific questions about how your credits affect your classification or if you think you may need to be reclassified, you can schedule time with an [academic adviser](https://psu.mediaspace.kaltura.

com/media/Make+an+Appointment+in+Starfish/1_xars485x) to help you interpret this information.  Professional academic advising resources are listed on your [Starfish Success Network](https://psu.starfishsolutions.com/starfish-ops/instructor/serviceCatalog.html#/).

concat.scalar:
You can talk with your instructor about using generative AI tools to complete assignments. The syllabus will often list information about the use of these tools in the classroom.
Currently, [Penn State's AI guidelines](https://ai.psu.edu/guidelines/) recommend [Microsoft Copilot](https://office365.psu.edu/microsoft-copilot/) for course-related use.

Penn State has contracted with Microsoft to ensure that information entered into Copilot is secure, confidential, and not used to train the tool itself. You do not need to create an account and already have access to it through Penn State authentication.
AI-generated content may not always be perfect or up-to-date. You'll want to verify any important information.

concat.scalar: The [Student Code of Conduct](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/student-accountability/code-procedures/student-code-conduct) ensures your rights as a student are protected and outlines the universityâ€™s expectations for your behavior as a Penn State student. It is your responsibility to review the Code and understand what items and/or behavior is prohibited both on and off campus.

In addition, Penn State's policy for [Weapons and Fireworks Regulations, Fireworks, and Paintball Devices](https://policy.psu.edu/policies/sy12#:~:text=The%20possession%2C%20carrying%2C%20or%20use,specifically%20authorized%20by%20the%20University.) states the possession, carrying, or use of any weapon, ammunition,

or explosive by any person is prohibited on all University property except by authorized law enforcement officers and other persons specifically authorized by the University. Any University student or employee who violates these prohibitions shall be subject to discipline in accordance with regular University procedures, which may include suspension or dismissal from the University.

Visitors to the University will be subject to appropriate trespass actions for failure to comply with these regulations. Further, if possession or use of a weapon, fireworks or paintball device is in violation of the law, it will be referred to University Police or other proper law enforcement authorities.
For students living in on-campus housing,

your [housing contract](https://liveon.psu.edu/) also provides terms, conditions, and regulations (TCRs) in addition to the Code and SY12.
The Office of Ethics and Compliance provides options for a student to [report an issue or concern](https://universityethics.psu.edu/reporting-at-penn-state/student).

concat.scalar: They employ a team of knowledgeable and compassionate clinicians and support staff who are able to diagnose and treat [routine illnesses, common health concerns and preexisting medical conditions](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/healthcare-and-medical-services/services). UHS also provides preventative care, education, and [resources](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/health-wellness/healthcare-and-

medical-services) to help students live a healthy lifestyle.
You can [schedule an appointment](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/healthcare-and-medical-services/schedule-appointment) for a time that meets your schedule during [operating hours](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/healthcare-and-medical-services/pharmacy/hours-parking).
If you need care when the University Health Services is closed, you may call the Advice Nurse at 1-814-865-4UHS (4847) (Press 3). A nurse is available 24/7.

[Penn State Brandywine Student Health Services](https://www.brandywine.psu.edu/student-life/student-health-services) provides first aid care, health care referrals, and wellness programs throughout the year.
[Student Health Services](https://harrisburg.psu.edu/student-health-services) provides quality health care, educational, and preventive health services to Penn State Harrisburg students.

University Health Services participates with a [limited number of insurance plans](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/healthcare-and-medical-services/policies-patient-resources/billing-medical-services). Please check with your insurance plan to determine if you are covered when seeking care.
Students who do not currently have adequate coverage on or near the campus they attend,

are strongly encouraged to enroll in the [Student Health Insurance Plan (SHIP) for Penn State](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/health-insurance). The SHIP for Penn State, designed specifically for students, offers comprehensive health insurance at a competitive price with a wide network of providers across the United States.

Uninsured or underinsured students can contact Student Care and Advocacy through the [Basic Needs Request Form](https://cm.maxient.com/reportingform.php?PennState&layout_id=27) to research health insurance plan options. The staff can help students determine if they qualify for government-subsidized health insurance plans such as Medicaid.

concat.scalar: Penn State Harrisburg offers [two honors programs](https://harrisburg.psu.edu/honors-program) for students who are highly motivated to achieve academic excellence and want more out of their college education. The two programs are the Capital College Honors Program and the Universityâ€™s Schreyer Honors College.
Both programs provide students with special honors courses in a wide variety of disciplines, supervised research opportunities, and support for international travel and study abroad.

The [Cooper and Schreyer Honors Programs](https://www.brandywine.psu.edu/academics/honors-programs)  at Penn State Brandywine support and encourage the diverse group of students who dedicate the time and effort it takes to be a scholar.  The devoted faculty and staff promote critical thinking and academic achievement in an intellectually stimulating environment.

Students are motivated to make a difference and create sustainable changes for the environment, the community, and the members of campus via faculty-guided research, service-learning projects, and volunteering on and off campus.

The [Schreyer Honors College](https://www.shc.psu.edu/) is widely and consistently recognized as one of the top undergraduate programs in the United States. With access to distinguished faculty, smaller honors class sizes, and individualized support, the honors experience at Penn State is designed to position students for success.

The Honors College promotes achieving academic excellence with integrity, building a global perspective and creating opportunities for leadership and civic engagement.
Joining the Honors College means that you will join a [group of dynamic, diverse students](https://www.shc.psu.edu/life/community/) who define the best in academic achievement,

but who are also committed to changing their communities, their workplaces, and the world for the better.
Honors courses are a central component to the [academic experience](https://www.shc.psu.edu/academics/) offered at the Schreyer Honors College.

Take one of the more than 300 of these honors courses offered across a huge range of subjects or work with your instructor to make a regular course into an honors course via an honors option.
The Schreyer Honors College welcomes [applications from students](https://www.shc.psu.edu/admissions/current-

student/) currently enrolled at Penn State or those transferring to Penn State from another institution. The application for current students is available from early March through mid-May for those meeting the eligibility criteria.
I didn't catch that. Select a valid option:

As a Schreyer Scholar, you are required to complete an [undergraduate honors thesis](https://www.shc.psu.edu/academics/thesis/) as the culmination of your honors experience. The goal of the thesis is to demonstrate a command of relevant scholastic work and to make a personal contribution to that scholarship.

Your thesis project can take many forms â€” from laboratory experiments all the way to artistic creations. Your thesis document captures the relevant background, methods, and techniques and describes the details of the completion of the individual project.

concat.scalar: The transfer process and eligibility requirements for student athletes to be recruited to play for another school are specific to each campus.

The NCAA [Transfer Portal](https://www.ncaa.org/sports/2015/2/13/want-to-transfer.aspx) allows a student-athlete the opportunity to be recruited to play for another school after the student informs their current school that they wish to transfer to another university. The institution then has two business days to enter that athlete's name into a national transfer portal. Once the student-

athlete's name is in the database, other coaches from any school can contact that individual.
If you are a student-athlete who is considering transferring from Penn State to another university, please work through our [Compliance Office contacts](https://universityethics.psu.edu/our-team) and your [Morgan Academic Center Counselor](https://morgancenter.psu.edu/about-us/staff-
directory/) for guidance on the transfer process and eligibility requirements.

steps.title: Abington, Altoona, Behrend, Berks, Brandywine, Harrisburg

concat.scalar: The NCAA [Transfer Portal](https://www.ncaa.org/sports/2015/2/13/want-to-transfer.aspx) is only accessible to NCAA Division I, Division II, and Division III coaches and administrators and allows a student-athlete the opportunity to be recruited to play for another school after the student informs their current school that they wish to transfer to another university.

The institution then has two business days to enter that athlete's name into a national transfer portal. Once the student-athlete's name is in the database, other coaches from any school can contact that individual.
Since not all Division III schools use the NCAA Transfer Portal, if you are a Division III student-

athlete wishing to have any direct or indirect recruiting communication with any future Division I or II school, you need to request written permission to contact from the compliance office at your school. If this request is denied for any reason, you may request a hearing opportunity to proceed with an appeal with the current Division III school.

If you are a current Division III student-athlete wishing to contact another Division III school, you can [download the Division III self-release form](https://www.ncaa.org/sports/2013/11/19/division-iii-compliance-forms.aspx). This form includes instructions on how to complete and submit the form to the new Division III school. If the initial 30-

day contact period expires after submitting the first form, and you are still undecided, you must submit a second self-release form, which then requires the new Division III school to notify the current school of this recruiting activity.

The NCAA [Transfer Portal](https://www.ncaa.org/sports/2015/2/13/want-to-transfer.aspx) is only accessible to NCAA Division I, Division II, and Division III institutions (coaches and administrators).
If you are a student-athlete who is considering transferring from Penn State to another university,
please contact your coach or Athletic Director for guidance on the transfer process and eligibility requirements.

concat.scalar: [Swapping a class](https://pennstate.service-now.com/kb?id=kb_article_view&sysparm_article=KB0018812&sys_kb_id=2e7f58c6878b1d109b7d7484dabb35ad&spa=1) provides a way for you to drop a class you are currently enrolled in and replace it with a new class.  Since this process is done simultaneously, it is a way to keep your space in the enrolled class while trying to enroll in a new class.

Students are advised not to set up a Swap for classes that have a related Class Component (e.g., required lecture and recitation) they are already enrolled in. This scenario may cause the Swap to fail, and students may be unintentionally dropped from their original class without getting swapped into the desired class.
To [swap with a waitlisted class](https://tutorials.lionpath.psu.

edu/public/S_SwapClass/), select an alternative class and schedule it, then in LionPATH, request a swap with the [waitlisted course](https://advising.psu.edu/node/650). If the first choice becomes available, the alternative course will be swapped for the first choice course.
University wide [academic dates and deadlines](https://www.registrar.psu.edu/academic-

calendars/) are available through the Office of the University Registrar.
You can discuss your plans to swap a course with an [academic adviser](https://psu.mediaspace.kaltura.com/media/Make+an+Appointment+in+Starfish/1_xars485x). Your assigned adviser and professional academic advising resources are listed on your [Starfish Success Network](https://psu.starfishsolutions.com/starfish-
ops/instructor/serviceCatalog.html#/).

concat.scalar: Students at the Brandywine campus may use the [printers](https://www.brandywine.psu.edu/academics/information-technology-services/resources) connected to lab machines as much as they need to, provided it's for academic purposes.

[Penn State IT](https://www.it.psu.edu/services/) provides a modern cloud-based, pay-as-you-go [printing service](https://pawprints.psu.edu) offering convenience and individualized experiences for students, faculty, staff, and visitors at the Abington, Altoona, Beaver, Berks, Dickinson Law, Fayette, Harrisburg, Hazleton, Hershey Medical, Lehigh Valley, New Kensington, Schuylkill, Scranton,

and University Park campuses.
The [Paw Prints kiosks](https://pawprints.psu.edu/#locations) provide an easy and convenient way to print and scan documents in both black and white and color. The kiosks are powered by wepa, who has partnered with PrintReleaf to reforest trees and achieve a paper-neutral footprint.
Students at the Harrisburg campus can pick up [free Paw Print cards](https://harrisburg.psu.edu/student-advocacy/resources/printing) at several campus offices.

actions.title: How to print at Penn State

concat.scalar: For undergraduate students, a full-time course load is 12 credits a semester.  To [graduate on a 4-year (8-semester) timeline](https://www.registrar.psu.edu/degree-planning/), most undergraduate degrees require students to earn 15 credits toward degree requirements each semester. This translates to taking five 3-credit courses each semester. Most first-year students take between 14-17 credits.

The combination of courses you take, and the total number of credits needs to balance with your other life obligations, like working, commuting, family care, etc. The number of courses you take (and their total number of credits) also affects your eligibility for certain student organizations, scholarships, financial aid, and athletic participation.

These are great topics to discuss with your [academic adviser](https://psu.mediaspace.kaltura.com/media/Make+an+Appointment+in+Starfish/1_xars485x) listed in your [Starfish Success Network](https://psu.starfishsolutions.com/starfish-ops/instructor/serviceCatalog.html#/).

concat.scalar: [The Daily Collegian](https://www.psucollegian.com) and its predecessors serve as an important source for documenting student life at the Pennsylvania State University. The Daily Collegian originally started as The Freelance in 1887 and then changed names several times time before landing on its current name on September 5th, 1940.

Penn State libraries offers a [digitized collection](https://libraries.psu.edu/about/collections/digital-newspapers/daily-collegian-historical#:~:text=The%20Daily%20Collegian%20and%20its,at%20the%20Pennsylvania%20State%20University%20.) of The Daily Collegian for years 1887 to 2010.
If you are interested in learning how to [join](https://www.psucollegian.

com/join/) The Daily Collegeian or have any questions, you can email the Editor-In-Chief at editorinchief@psucollegian.com.
As a Penn State student, you also have digital access to a variety of [local, national, and global newspapers](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/involvement-student-life/student-services/student-news-readership-program) at no cost.

concat.scalar: [Penn State](https://www.psu.edu/about/history) is a major public research university serving the Pennsylvania Commonwealth. There are [twenty-four campuses](https://bulletins.psu.edu/undergraduate/campuses/) across Pennsylvania, as well as an [online World Campus](https://www.worldcampus.psu.edu/) that serve students and communities as we carry out our mission of teaching, research, and service.

There are [more than 85,000 students](https://www.psu.edu/about/facts-and-rankings) enrolled across the Universityâ€™s campuses. The University was founded in 1855, when the Commonwealth chartered it as a college of agricultural science to apply scientific principles to farming. Today, [Penn State](https://www.psu.edu/) has a broad mission of teaching, research, and public service.

The University was founded in 1855, when the Commonwealth chartered it as a college of agricultural science to apply scientific principles to farming. Today, [Penn State](https://www.psu.edu/) has a broad mission of teaching, research, and public service. With a [campus near almost every Pennsylvania resident](https://www.psu.edu/academics/campuses) and global online options,

Penn State's world-class education is available to meet students where they are. There is only one Penn State and the [path toward a degree](https://www.psu.edu/academics/undergraduate/majors) can start wherever is right for you.
Pursuing a Penn State degree means access to faculty experts and state-of-the-art resources that will help you make an impact on the world.

Explore all degree options ranging from more than [275 undergraduate majors](https://www.psu.edu/academics/undergraduate), including top-ranked programs like engineering and business, to more than [300 graduate and professional programs](https://www.psu.edu/academics/graduate), including medical and legal studies.
The current [President](https://www.psu.

edu/president) of Penn State is Neeli Bendapudi. Neeli Bendapudi began her tenure as the nineteenth president of Penn State on May 9, 2022. With a nearly thirty-year career as a leader in higher education and business, Bendapudi is a dedicated educator, academic, and executive. The Office of the President is located at 201 Old Main University Park, PA.

concat.scalar:
I'm so sorry to hear that you're struggling. It's important to know that you're not alone.
Some symptoms of depression and anxiety can be common during the college experience and do not require seeking mental health services. It's advisable to reach out for help when these concerns disrupt your daily functioning and responsibilities, including- but not limited to- sleep, hygiene,

appetite/eating, class attendance, suicidal thoughts, and thoughts of harming yourself or others.
Help is available for enrolled Penn State students at your [campus counseling center](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/caps-campuses). You can reach out to [Counseling and Psychological Services (CAPS)](https://studentaffairs.psu.

edu/counseling) for confidential support and advocacy related to mental health issues, including depression. At University Park, you can call them at 814-863-0395 during business hours or visit their website. Additionally, you can also contact the 24/7 Penn State Crisis Line at <a href="tel:18772296400">1-877-229-

6400 or text LIONS to 741741 for immediate support.
Furthermore, Penn State has partnered with WellTrack, an online therapy platform for stress, anxiety, and depression, which is free to all students and can be accessed through the App Store or Google Play using your @psu.edu email to register. Remember, you don't have to face this alone,
and seeking help is a sign of strength.

If there is a medical emergency as a result of drinking or drug use, immediately call 911.
Each [Penn State campus](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/caps-campuses) has a unique set of mental health resources including wellness and prevention, [counseling services](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling), and urgent/emergency services,

such as the 24/7 [Penn State Crisis Line](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/crisis-intervention) 1-877-229-6400 or crisis textline (text LIONS to 741741).
Pennsylvania's [Medical Amnesty Law](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/health-wellness/alcohol-amnesty) states that, if an individual, in good faith,

calls and believes they are the first to call 911, police, ambulance or campus security, gives their name and stays with the person to prevent that person's death or serious injury, the caller is immune from prosecution for consumption or possession of alcohol and/or drugs.

concat.scalar:
[MyResource](https://myresource.psu.edu/) is a 24/7 student resource hub that can answer questions and provide resources related to undergraduate academics, basic needs, careers, belonging, engagement, mental health, wellness and safety at Penn State.
The MyResource knowledge base is trained on Penn State websites and other content related to these topics.

It uses traditional and generative artificial intelligence (AI) to create responses to your questions. AI-generated content may not always be perfect or up-to-date. Users should verify any important information.
For the best experience consider logging in with your Penn State credentials. This will cater answers relevent to your campus, major, and other personalized information.

Whether you log in or not, the MyResource team may collect the following information: Campus, chat questions and answers. This information will be solely used in de-identified or aggregate forms for the business purposes of streamlining access to student resources, building upon current students care resources to meet needs, foster well-being, support academic and personal goals,

and enhancing services and delivery. Your information and inputs will never be shared in identifiable form.
Curious how you can get involved on campus? Where to get a resume reviewed? How to find counseling options on campus? Ask a question to get started!

Details about your academic record are needed to answer questions about completing your degree.
If you have not yet declared your major, use a [What If Report](https://www.lionpath.psu.edu/psc/CSPRD/EMPLOYEE/SA/c/NUI_FRAMEWORK.PT_AGSTARTPAGE_NUI.

GBL?CONTEXTIDPARAMS=TEMPLATE_ID%3aPTPPNAVCOL&scname=PE_PT_NVF_DEGREE_PLAN&PanelCollapsible=Y&PTPPB_GROUPLET_ID=PE_PT_NVI_DEGREE_PLANNING&CRefName=PE_PT_NVI_DEGREE_PLANNING&ptgpid=PE_S201901301331005697690372&AJAXTransfer=y) for the major you intend. If you have already declared your major, use your [Academic Requirements Report](https://www.lionpath.psu.edu/psc/CSPRD/EMPLOYEE/SA/c/NUI_FRAMEWORK.

PT_AGSTARTPAGE_NUI.GBL?CONTEXTIDPARAMS=TEMPLATE_ID%3aPTPPNAVCOL&scname=PE_PT_NVF_DEGREE_PLAN&PanelCollapsible=Y&PTPPB_GROUPLET_ID=PE_PT_NVI_DEGREE_PLANNING&CRefName=PE_PT_NVI_DEGREE_PLANNING&ptgpid=PE_S201901181044283044539835&AJAXTransfer=y).
All majors, minors, and certificates are listed in the [Undergraduate Bulletin](https://bulletins.psu.edu/undergraduate/).

The default issue of the Bulletin is for students admitted to Penn State for this current academic year. Be sure to look at the Bulletin published in the [academic year](https://bulletins.psu.edu/undergraduate/archive/) you were admitted to Penn State. Each entry includes information about which campus offers the program.

Each major has a â€œHow to Get Inâ€ section that lists entrance requirements and also a suggested academic plan and major requirements.
Please meet with an [academic adviser](https://psu.mediaspace.kaltura.com/media/Make+an+Appointment+in+Starfish/1_xars485x) to review your degree progress and make sure you are correctly interpreting your academic records.

Your assigned adviser and professional academic advising resources are listed on your [Starfish Success Network](https://psu.starfishsolutions.com/starfish-ops/instructor/serviceCatalog.html#/).
You can [apply for graduation](https://www.lionpath.psu.edu/psc/CSPRD/EMPLOYEE/SA/c/NUI_FRAMEWORK.PT_AGSTARTPAGE_NUI.

If you need to apply after the intent period has closed, please consult with your [graduation coordinator](https://www.registrar.psu.edu/graduation/college-contact-directory.cfm).

concat.scalar: If you or a friend are experiencing a mental health emergency, get immediate help by calling 911 or contacting the [Penn State Crisis Line](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/crisis-intervention) 24/7 at 1-877-229-6400 or crisis textline (text LIONS to 741741).

Comprehensive health care resources are available through [University Health Services (UHS)](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/health) at University Park and at most [Penn State campuses](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/health-wellness/medical-services/health-services-commonwealth-campuses).

They specialize in outpatient student health including the treatment of medically urgent problems and ongoing health concerns. They also provide preventative care, education, and resources to help students live a healthy lifestyle.
If you or a friend are in immediate danger, call 911.

At all times, students are encouraged to [notify the university](https://universityethics.psu.edu/reporting-at-penn-state/hazing-students) as soon as possible when they become aware that [hazing](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/involvement-student-life/greek-life-penn-state/hazing-sexual-assault-alcohol) has, or may, occur.
Reports can be filed with the Office of Student Accountability & Conflict Response, or submitted anonymously to the Office of Ethics and Compliance.
If you were a witness to a situation, you can [report a concern](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/report) or [violation](https://universityethics.psu.edu/reporting-at-penn-state).

You may talk to a [confidential advocate](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/victim-survivor-support-advocacy/immediate-assistance) at the [Relationship Violence Outreach, Intervention, and Community Education (R-VOICE) CenterÂ ](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/r-voice) or a [counselor](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/crisis-

intervention) through [Counseling and Psychological Services (CAPS) at University Park](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling) or [counseling services on your campus](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/caps-campuses).
You have many options for reporting sexual or gender-based harassment or misconduct. You may submit an incident report online,

meet with someone from the Office of Sexual Misconduct Reporting and Response, file an anonymous report through a hotline, and/or file a criminal complaint with the University Police Department or local police department.
You can [make a report](https://universityethics.psu.edu/our-expertise/title-ix/report) to Penn State's Office of Ethics and Compliance.

You can [make a report to law enforcement](https://www.police.psu.edu/) with the agency that has jurisdiction over the location where the incident occurred.
Under Title IX and Penn Stateâ€™s Sexual Harassment policy, [AD 85](https://policy.psu.edu/policies/ad85), supportive measures are available as appropriate for a complainant or respondent.

You can [borrow laptops and iPads](https://libraries.psu.edu/services/technology-equipment) from the University Libraries for up to 7 days with a valid PSU ID. The libraries provide a wide variety of technology equipment and services available for academic, research, professional, and personal use.

[Wireless service](https://pennstate.service-now.com/sp?id=it_service_offering_request_forms&offering_id=52aedfba0ff1b100f178317ce1050e30)  is available indoors at most Penn State buildings and broadcasts multiple wireless networks to support a variety of needs.

For assistance with personal or university-owned devices, you can connect with [Penn State IT](https://www.it.psu.edu/support/) consultants in person, by phone, or online to discuss your situation and the support they can provide.
For personal devices, review this [knowledge base support article](https://pennstate.service-now.

com/sp?id=kb_article&sysparm_article=KB0015888&sys_kb_id=3021ce29978f9d102dc779cfe153afdc&spa=1) for hardware support options. com/sp?id=kb_article&sysparm_article=KB0016662&sys_kb_id=c188a87e87f4c210e0624c8e0ebb355d&spa=1). owned devices, contact your local [IT Support](https://www.it.psu.edu/support/) for assistance with requesting new equipment, loaner equipment, or equipment repairs. Scroll down to the Campus IT Service Desks or the College IT Help Desks, to contact your local IT support.

concat.scalar: The [Nittany Lion](https://www.psu.edu/news/campus-life/story/origin-nittany-lion/) is the athletic mascot for Penn State teams, known as the Penn State Nittany Lions. The mascot is a mountain lion, once a common predator in Pennsylvania and has been used since 1921. The name "Nittany" is derived from the Algonquian word Nit-A-Nee meaning "single mountainâ€ referring to Mount Nittany,

a landmark near the University's Park campus that overlooks the valley.
In 1942, Heinz Warneke carved the Nittany Lion Shrine from a 13-ton block of Indiana limestone. The Nittany Lion Shrine is a physical representation of the University's mascot. However, it's more than just a campus landmark. The [Nittany Lion Shrine](https://www.psu.edu/about/nittany-lion-

shrine) is an emotional touchpoint for Penn Staters everywhere.
Today, Nittany Lion Shrine replicas watch over all of Penn State's campuses throughout Pennsylvania.

When requesting a letter of recommendation from a professor, adviser, or other faculty, here are some things you need to know:
Recommenders should know you personally and be able to speak to your specific strengths. It is common courtesy to ask if a person is willing to provide a recommendation at least two weeks prior to the submission deadline. If possible,

set up an appointment with your recommender to talk about the opportunity you are seeking and why you are asking them to write a letter. It is perfectly fine to say, â€œI thought you would be a good recommender because you know xxx about me best.â€
If you get the sense that the person is hesitant to write the letter, find someone else to write one for you.

If the person agrees to write the letter, give them a completed and signed [Request for Letter of Recommendation form](https://registrar.psu.edu/student-forms/request-letter-recommendation.cfm). You will also need to provide the recipient's contact information, the submission deadline, and any other materials that will inform their statement (for example, a copy of your resume, transcript,
draft personal statement/cover letter).

Since student grades are part of the education record, they are protected under FERPA and, therefore, may not be released to parents.  When the student reaches the age of 18 or begins attending a postsecondary institution, regardless of age, [FERPA rights transfer](https://www.ed.gov/laws-and-policy/ferpa/ferpa-overview) from the parent to the student.

This means that parents may not obtain any of their student's education records without the written consent of the student.
Students may provide [consent for their parent to view grades](https://www.registrar.psu.edu/confidentiality/parent-rights.cfm) and other portions of their education record via LionPATH.

concat.scalar: Penn State CAPS at University Park offers the [Nurture in Nature](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/nurture-nature) initiative to bring the benefits of being outdoors to students in safe, convenient, and accessible ways.

Nurture in Nature Penn State Wellness Trails were developed with the intention of making it easier for all students and community members alike to access and intentionally connect with nature. The trails are free to use and invite trail-goers to be mindful while doing so. At various points on each trail, there are invitations for trail-goers to participate in self-
guided activities that aim to enhance the benefits of already being in a natural place. Trail-goers should feel free to accept these invitations as they are or adapt them to meet their own needs.

concat.scalar: Students may want to seek confidential support that is not related to gender-based harassment or sexual harassment. Penn State counseling centers at all campuses follow all professional standards and state and federal laws. Information shared with the therapist is held in the [strictest confidence](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/department-directory/counseling-psychological-services/about-

counseling-psychological-services-2#) consistent with professional and ethical standards and state and federal law. Therapists will not release information without the client's signed consent except in rare instances where sharing is required by law (such as to save a human life, to report child sexual abuse, or to comply with a court order).

Students may want to speak with someone confidentially about an incident of gender-based harassment or sexual harassment. [Confidential resources](https://universityethics.psu.edu/our-expertise/title-ix/t9-resources/confidential) will not disclose information about the incident,

and seeking advice from a confidential counselor does not constitute a report to the University or law enforcement. This includes the [Relationship Violence Outreach, Intervention, and Community Education (R-VOICE) Center](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/r-voice) at University Park, and the [Center for Sexual and Gender Diversity](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/csgd) at University Park,

and the [counseling centers at all Penn State campuses](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/counseling/caps-campuses).
You can find more information in the [Title IX Frequently Asked Questions](https://universityethics.psu.edu/our-expertise/title-ix/about-title-ix/t9-faq).

concat.scalar: All students (undergraduate, graduate, continuing education, part-time, full-time, or adjunct) wishing to use [parking facilities at University Park campus](https://map.psu.edu/?id=1134#!ce/25402?ct/25403,26748,26749,26750,27255?s/) (at any time, for any reason), including Innovation Park and the Technology Support Building,

must register their vehicle with Transportation Services according to the [parking regulations](https://transportation.psu.edu/student-parking-regulations), and while parked on campus, properly display an authorized parking permit. More information about student eligibility rules, parking rates and lot locations,

permit options and other parking situations is available on the [Transportations Services website](https://transportation.psu.edu/student-parking).
Penn State students and employees are not considered visitors, except for Commonwealth Campus students not enrolled in classes at University Park. [Commonwealth Campus student permits](https://transportation.psu.edu/commonwealth-campus-
parking) are not valid at University Park at any time. You can [pay for parking at select areas with the ParkMobile app](https://transportation.psu.edu/daily-visitor-parking) or at pay stations.

[To park on campus](https://map.concept3d.com/?id=1140#!ce/28020?s/), all students must display a Penn State Brandywine parking permit on the rear view mirror of the vehicle and are expected to abide by the [campus](https://www.brandywine.psu.edu/police-public-safety/parking) and University parking policies.

All Penn State Harrisburg students must register their vehicles each semester and display a current parking permit to [park in the campus parking lots](https://harrisburg.psu.edu/map?id=1146#!ce/26447?ct/35058,28203,0,26447,30200?mc/40.20221599835232,-76.74472547136249?z/16?lvl/0). All students and employees are expected to abide by the [campus](https://harrisburg.psu.edu/vehicle-registration-
parking) and University parking policies.

This [Free Food Map](https://hhd.psu.edu/shm/research/industry-research-and-

thought-leadership/food-decisions-research-laboratory-fdrl/fdrl-free) identifies locations throughout Centre County and Pennsylvania that offer free food to those in need.
In addition, many colleges have resources available to help, including the [College of Liberal Arts](https://la.psu.edu/current-students/current-students-funding/emergency-funding/),

[College of Agricultural Sciences](https://agsci.psu.edu/students/scholarships/emergency-loan-funds), and [Ross and Carol Nese College of Nursing](https://www.nursing.psu.edu/financial-aid/). You can check with your college regarding any available emergency funds.
If you would like additional support,

Student Care and Advocacy can guide you to the best [resources](https://studentaffairs.psu.edu/basic-needs-support) based on your need and provide support and ongoing assistance, as appropriate.
You can also schedule a confidential meeting with a [professional financial coach](https://financialliteracy.psu.edu/) to discuss your finances and help tackle your unique challenges.

The [Penn State Brandywine Campus Food Pantry](https://socialimpact.bw.psu.edu/programs/foodpantry/) provides an on-campus food pantry available to all students experiencing food insecurity. This [Free Food Map](https://hhd.psu.edu/shm/research/industry-research-and-thought-leadership/food-decisions-research-laboratory-fdrl/fdrl-

free) identifies locations throughout Pennsylvania that offer free food to those in need. Additional community resources are provided on their website.
In addition, the Brandywine Student Affairs Office is one office that can best assist you in meeting your basic needs by submitting a [Care Report form](https://cm.maxient.com/reportingform.php?PennState=&layout_id=14).

The Penn State Harrisburg [Student Advocacy Office](https://harrisburg.psu.edu/student-advocacy) is one office that can best [assist you in meeting your basic needs](https://cm.maxient.com/reportingform.php?PennState&layout_id=27).
The [WE cARE Pantry](https://harrisburg.psu.edu/student-advocacy/food-insecurity) is free to all students and provides culturally diverse foods,

personal care products, and cleaning supplies. This [Free Food Map](https://hhd.psu.edu/shm/research/industry-research-and-thought-leadership/food-decisions-research-laboratory-fdrl/fdrl-free) identifies locations throughout Pennsylvania that offer free food to those in need.
You may [self-schedule a meeting](https://outlook.office365.
com/book/PennStateUniversity2293333@PennStateOffice365.onmicrosoft.com/) with any case manager to further discuss your needs and learn about possible assistance.
